children.subject: Probably a junior, taking 168 as a freshman is kinda sus
Current junior
Just wondering, are you a current sophomore or junior?

history.content: 126: Probably overkill for your exact goals, good general statistical thinking knowledge but a lot of focus on applications (lot of communications / networks focus) that aren't particularly what you're focusing on (correct me if I'm wrong). Common alternatives I believe are Stat 134 and 140, although I haven't taken either so someone would have to add if they do fulfill everything you're looking for.

children.subject: And fwiw 126 is an awesome and very fun course. Courtade and Ramchandran are both awesome profs and the course staff are super helpful and enthusiastic. If you have the time, I would definitely recommend it.
If I take it, I’m likely going to take 126 in the fall with Parekh, although I’ve heard he’s not as great as the others. Do you know if there’s a big difference between his offering and theirs?

I'm in 126 right now and while taking past exams to study for midterms, I notice Parekh's tests feel much harder, at least to me, than Ramachandran's tests (and Courtade's current tests we have been taking)
@Anonymous Mouse: I'm curious what specific topics that are useful to quant finance but not covered in data 140 ?

@Anon Poet if you have questions on 140, I am on course staff and would be glad to answer! 140 is pretty comprehensive for quant, fun fact: people like to use the 140 textbook exercises to study for quant interviews!

@Anon Beaker Thanks ! I'm actually debating between which classes to take. Are there any benefits of taking 140 over 126 if I got a high A for cs 70 ? Since you have taken both, what is the difference between 2 courses ? What would I miss out if I take 140 instead of 126 ? I'm interested in how probability is applicable to finance and data science in general.
I'm leaning towards 140 for now because my probability skill in 70 is still fresh, and I don't want to take ee 126 next fall.

Of the probability offerings (126, 140, whatever else there is), what do you recommend for someone who wants to get better at probability and can potentially help with quant/trading interviews or jobs? I got an A in CS 70, but that was a while ago and I've forgotten probably a bit of the content.

I've taken 189 so I'm not as focused on which one provides better prep for that.

Overall, I’d say taking 140 gave me more than enough knowledge in terms of having a great probability/stats foundation. I would be happy and confident with just 140. I can’t speak much as to quant interviews personally but all my friends who did just 140 for quant have landed pretty great roles. I took 126 mainly just cause I was a senior and felt like 126 would be an interesting last class to take since I love stats, but these courses do have pretty substantial overlap.

I think the difference between the courses lies in the last 1/3 of each tbh (a lot of people say the second 1/2 but I don’t feel that’s true as both cover DTMCs, convergence, and Poisson Processes). The last 1/3 of 140 covers more probability distributions (Gamma, Beta, Cauchy, etc.) which you won’t see in 126. I personally have heard that these distributions (Gamma especially) are great for modeling situations in econ and epidemiology. The last 1/3 of 126 seems to be covering things like Kalman filters, Hidden Markov Models, etc. I am interested in robotics which is why I was compelled to take 126, but I do not believe these have much quant application (again someone can correct me if I’m wrong as I have no quant background)

I may be biased (as I'm 140 staff) but I feel like in my experience with both courses 140 is more readily applicable to real-world tasks based on all the real-world coding problems on our hws/labs. Not to say 126 doesn't provide this either!
To add on to Beaker's comment about Parekh's exams being harder, I've heard his curve was extremely generous so don't let difficulty stop you.
^ yeah that is definitely the case

<md>Student answer is misinformed about the usefulness of 126. This class is very applicable to industry if your goals are quant finance. The applications are also geared towards engineering and could provide some nice background to the stuff you learned in 188 and 189</md>

I'm taking 161 and it's definitely interesting, though I'm not sure how much less you would gain after having taken 162 and 168 (I've taken neither). The workload isn't that high imo so it shouldn't be a huge burden, but I'd recommend taking a look through some of the slides (cs161.org) to see how much you already know.

I took 164 with Prof Sen during Fa19. I would say it's worth taking if you're actually interested in compilers, but it hasn't applied to industry as much for me (I mostly do frontend swe). The project work was time-consuming around the deadlines. I didn't coordinate to find a project partner prior to enrolling though, I don't think that's necessary. You can just ask around on Piazza or talk to people in class or something. Overall I did enjoy the content!
Just curious, are 164 projects written mainly in OCaml?
When I took the class, we compiled ChocoPy (a subset of Python: https://chocopy.org/) to RISC-V using Java with JFlex and CUP.
Does anyone have insight into the other classes? The post is now marked as resolved even though 5/6 of my questions are still left unanswered.

history.content:
Been trying to plan out my schedule using the draft schedule so far, and wanted to hear opinions and experiences on the classes listed below. These are just going to be general interest/learning classes as I won't have any issue hitting the grad requirements. I've taken D100, 162, 170, 188, 189 and I'm trying to optimize for general learning and future industry work.

  • 126: I feel like I want to take a probability course for general statistical thinking knowledge and perhaps for recruiting purposes, but I'm not sure if 126 is overload for that purpose and likely the recruiting timeline will be already started and I won't get to leverage the knowledge from this class fully. Are there other easier/lower workload probability classes that you'd recommend instead? Thoughts appreciated.
  • 161: How is this and what's the workload like? Is the content useful or interesting? I've taken 162 and 168 already for context
  • 164: seems interesting in the sense that it covers low-level language design stuff, but it also feels like a big workload. I also wouldn't have friends/team to take this with. Is that a dealbreaker?
  • 182: I probably want to take this (really interested in subject matter), unless it's just a terrible class or too much work
  • 184: seems interesting and it would be cool to make pretty pictures with. How technically and mathematically challenging is this?
  • 186: Databases are important to know especially in industry. But this class seems overkill if I just want to know how to use databases (ie. with sql or graphql), and am not actually designing them myself.

Any advice on good parings of classes also recommended (eg. content complements each other or workloads are manageable together). thanks in advance!
history.subject: Thoughts on these upper divs?
